Conventional heat supply systems for indoor environments merely show annual efficiencies of net energy usage for room heating of 70% to 80% due to an inertia-related oversupply in unoccupied periods. In this study, a new method for increasing this efficiency is introduced. Low-capacity, direct electric heating systems are used to realize an occupancy-equivalent heating concept which only heats the room during occupancy. Using a fast-responding infrared sensor, these heating systems can be controlled by operative temperature, preventing significant oversupplies whilst rapidly heating up a space. A model-based algorithm enables a setback of the room temperature in unoccupied periods while guaranteeing a predefined temperature in the beginning of occupied periods. Thus, the control algorithm enables a utility-equivalent heating operation compared to a non-setback operation. During a first parameter study, net energy savings of up to 21% could be realized due to the new control method compared to a conventional schedule-based operation. The reheating factor of the heat supply system is identified as the main indicator affecting the energy saving potential in occasionally occupied rooms. Keywords Operative temperature control Occupancy-equivalent heating Direct electric heating Radiative heating Heat transfer Data availability Data will be made available on request. As these heat supply systems cannot be controlled immediately, rooms are also heated in (short-term) unoccupied periods. While evaluating heating operation in unoccupied rooms as heat loss, a low-capacity heating system which can increase and decrease the room temperature instantly, shows potential for significantly improving the efficiency of net energy usage for room heating. As the adequacy of hot water based heating systems in nearly zero-energy buildings is highly discussed [4,5], there is a demand for energy-efficient, occupancy-equivalent solutions operating material-saving, direct electric heating systems. Occupancy-based room heating concepts have been analyzed in previous research [6]. The related control strategies are based on user-defined schedules (e.g. Iyengar et al. [7]), occupancy detection and monitoring (e.g. Peng et al. [8]) or combinations of both (e.g. Scott et al. [9]). Thereby, predictive control strategies show high potentials for energy savings by optimizing the heating operation in occupied and unoccupied periods [8]. Nevertheless, it must be noted that the energy saving potential strongly depends on the occupancy prediction accuracy. Balaji et al. [10] reported energy savings of 17.8% due to a reactive, occupancy-based control. However, the setback temperature during unoccupied periods is user-defined and not yet optimized. When resorting to conventional heat supply systems, the proposed, predictive and reactive control methods still cannot be used for an occupancy-equivalent room heating. The thermal inertia of the applied heat supply systems are too high for realizing fast-response heating-up processes [11]. Algorithms to predict occupancy- or schedule-based operations to start heat supply systems premature to occupied periods are still indispensable [12,13]. Schaub et al. [14] showed the energy saving potential using direct electric, low-capacity heating fabrics for intermittent occupancy by reducing the room temperature in unoccupied periods instantly. Although the proposed control method reveals a high potential, a comparison to a schedule-based operation is ineligible due to disparate utility levels (of thermal comfort) in the beginning of occupied periods. Consequently, this paper aims for a control strategy for direct electric, low-capacity heating fabrics exploiting all mentioned potentials in common and reducing the energy demand for room heating. The system shall respond quickly to short-term heat gains or losses and shall be set to an energy saving mode during unoccupied periods. Compared to a non-setback operation, a utility-equivalent, heating operation is focused. In comparison to the control concepts mentioned above, an occupancy-optimized heating concept is implemented without the need of preheating the room premature to occupied periods. As radiative heat transfer constitutes the major heat transfer process for direct electric surface heating systems, the operative temperature is used as a controlled variable. Besides a more precise description of the thermal comfort, a real-time measurement of the operative temperature allows accelerated heating-up processes of radiative heating systems. Sensors for an appropriate, practical measurement of the operative temperature (or additional consideration of the mean radiant temperature) have already been demonstrated in previous works [15,16] but do not fulfill the requirements of long- and real-time measurement capabilities at once. As conventional sensor systems (e.g. globe thermometers) cannot prevent a temporal oversupply (caused by the sensor’s induced dead time), an adequate, robust measurement is newly introduced in this study. The control method is developed in a simulation model allowing for reproducible boundary conditions comparing different use cases. Therefore, the generic room setup in Fig. 1 is designed as RC model and introduced in Section 2. Section 3 presents the proposed control method. 2 Analysis model The development of the control method and further energetic analyses are performed in the generic room setup in Fig. 1. The room with dimensions 5.8 × 3.98 × 3.03 m3 is equipped with six low-capacity PTC heating fabrics (Fig. 2). Considering the characteristic material properties and heat transfer mechanisms of surface heating systems and construction components, the generic room setup in Fig. 1 is designed as an RC model (Fig. 3) and implemented in Python and Modelica. Herein, components describe walls, windows, lighting, doors, heating fabrics and combinations of those. Corresponding, already validated models are adopted from Modelica Buildings library [17] and AixLib [18] library. Exact locations, dimensions and thermo-physical characteristics of all components are listed in Fig. 4. As being of central relevance for our investigation, the heating fabric model (Section 2.1), the convective heat exchange model (Section 2.2), the radiative heat exchange model (Section 2.3) and the simulation model for the mean radiant temperature sensor (Section 2.4) are explained in detail. Section 2.5 finally shows a validation of the developed models in an experimental setup identical to Fig. 1. 2.1 Heating fabric model The heating fabric (Fig. 2) is described as an RC model in Fig. 5. A thermal model connects the heating fabric capacity C h to the rear wall capacity C com,h as well as to the room air capacity C a and the other surfaces in the field of view C com,i . Conduction resistances R com and R surf are obtained by experimental surveys. While R surf ≪ R com , R com mainly results from a thermal decoupling from the rear wall by a 2mm expanded polystyrene insulation layer directing the heat transfer primarily into the room. Thus, heating-up processes can be performed independently from the rear wall’s thermal capacity and the building construction can still be used as a heat reservoir for daily cyclical loading and unloading, enabling a summer heat protection. An electric model determines the heat flux corresponding to the specific PTC behavior. The PTC resistance R ( T ) is a material property and individual for different heating fabrics. It is determined with data gained from a heating-up process by exponential regression. Eq. (1) is applied. (1) R ( T ) = R 0 ⋅ e α ( T − T 0 ) Herein, α defines the temperature coefficient. The converted heat flux Q ̇ h can be calculated by Eq. (2) considering the voltage U or the current I . (2) Q ̇ h = U I = I 2 R ( T ) = U 2 R ( T ) 2.2 Convective heat exchange The convective heat transfer between surfaces and the air volume of the room is determined using heat transfer coefficients h c and is calculated as (3) h c = Nu ⋅ λ L , where Nu is the Nusselt number, λ the thermal conductivity and L the length of the flow path. Thereby, Nu can be determined using empirical approximation equations considering the corresponding boundary conditions [19]. Nusselt numbers for convective heat transfer at planar, vertical plates with approximately homogeneous temperature distributions and a dominating natural convection are calculated as (4) Nu = 0 . 68 + 0 . 67 ⋅ Ra 1 4 1 + 0 . 492 Pr 9 16 4 9 , 0 ≤ Ra < 1 0 9 0 . 825 + 0 . 387 ⋅ Ra 1 6 1 + 0 . 492 Pr 9 16 8 27 2 , Ra ≥ 1 0 9 according to Churchill and Chu [20]. Herein, Ra defines the Rayleigh number and Pr the Prandtl number. Ra can be calculated using (5) Ra L = Gr L ⋅ Pr = g β a ( T surf − T a ) L 3 ν 2 ⋅ Pr and depends on the Grashof number Gr L and Pr . Thereby, Gr L is determined considering the thermal expansion coefficient β a and the kinematic viscosity ν of the room air, the length of the flow path L as well as surface and air temperatures T surf and T a . Empirical approximation equations for natural convection at horizontal plates are determined in Alamdari and Hammond [21]. h c is calculated using (6) h c = 1 . 4 Δ T d hyd 1 4 6 + 1 . 63 Δ T 1 3 6 1 6 for upward heat flows and (7) h c = 0 . 6 Δ T d hyd 2 1 5 for downward heat flows. Herein d hyd describes the hydraulic diameter calculated as (8) d hyd = 4 ⋅ A P , considering the surface area A and the perimeter P . 2.3 Radiative heat exchange Radiation exchange is modeled with a surface-to-surface radiation model presuming the room air as non-participating medium [22]. According to Minkina and Dudzik [23] this assumption is valid if distances between two arbitrary surfaces exchanging radiation do not exceed 10m. Presuming only opaque surfaces, the outgoing heat flux density q ̇ out , i of an arbitrary surface i ∈ [ 1 , … , N ] can be expressed as (9) q ̇ out , i = ϵ i σ T i 4 + ρ i q ̇ in , i = ϵ i σ T i 4 + ( 1 − ϵ i ) q ̇ in , i , where ϵ , ρ and T describe the emissivity, the reflectivity and the absolute temperature of surface i . σ defines the Stefan-Boltzmann constant. Considering the reciprocal relation Φ i → j A i = Φ j → i A j , the incoming heat flux density q ̇ in , i can be expressed as (10) q ̇ in , i = ∑ j = 1 N Φ i → j q ̇ out , j , where Φ i → j defines the view factor from surface i to surface j . Subsequently, radiation balance for surface i is expressed by Eq. (11). (11) q ̇ i = q ̇ out , i − q ̇ in , i = ϵ i 1 − ϵ i ( σ T i 4 − q ̇ out , i ) The equation system is solved with Python. For every pair of surfaces exchanging radiation, view factors are calculated initially to reduce computation effort. A Riemann sum is used to approximate Eq. (12a) by (12b) enabling a numerical solution [24]. Thereby, n i → and n j → describe normalized normal vectors of A i and A j , r k l → defines the direction vector from the center of area Δ A i to the center of area Δ A j . All components are visualized in Fig. 6. (12a) Φ i → j = 1 A i π ∫ A i ∫ A j cos φ i cos φ j r 2 d A j d A i (12b) ≈ − 1 A i π ∑ k = 1 m ∑ l = 1 m ( r k l → ⋅ n i → ) ( r l k → ⋅ n j → ) ‖ r k l → ‖ 4 Δ A j Δ A i Choosing a high value for m , the approximation error can be determined to 0.27% for the view factor calculation in the experimental test room in Fig. 1. Following the calculation of the convective heat transfer, a radiative heat transfer coefficient can be defined as (13) h r , i ↔ j = Φ i → j q ̇ out , i − q ̇ out , j T i − T j ︸ related to A i = Φ j → i q ̇ out , j − q ̇ out , i T j − T i ︸ related to A j . 2.4 Mean radiant temperature model According to Fanger [25], the mean radiant temperature can be expressed as (14) T r 4 = 1 σ ∑ i = 1 N q ̇ out , i Φ i where Φ i describes the view factor from a measurement point to a surface i . Eq. (14) can be simplified to Eq. (15) if high emissivities ( ≥ 0 , 9 ) predominate. A comparison of both methods only revealed non-significant deviations in the validation experiments. (15) T r 4 = ∑ i = 1 N T i 4 Φ i Φ i can be calculated using Eq. (16). Equivalent to Eq. (12), a Riemann sum is used for a numerical approximation. (16a) Φ i = 1 4 π ∫ A i cos φ r 2 d A i (16b) ≈ 1 4 π ∑ i = 1 m ( r i → ⋅ n → ) ‖ r i → ‖ 3 Δ A i 2.5 Experimental model validation The model validation takes place in an experimental test room identical to Fig. 1. A separate climate chamber with a constant temperature of -10°C connects to the test room’s entire outer wall (containing the windows) and enables transmission heat losses. In addition, ventilation heat losses are generated by a swirl diffuser in the center of the ceiling. During the validation experiments, the room is supplied with a constant air volume flow of 35m3 h−1 and a temperature of -1°C. The entire experimental setup is located in an enclosing test hall. The enclosing air temperature is controlled to 20°C by mixed ventilation. The experimental model validation is conducted in a two-step procedure. In a first step, the heating fabric model is validated comparing the simulated and the measured thermal behavior in a heating-up process. Secondly, the room model is validated comparing the thermal model behavior and the real room behavior in a dynamic experiment. 2.5.1 Heating fabric validation The heating-up process for validation purposes is illustrated in Fig. 7. Herein, the heating fabric reaches a peak power of approx. 420W. The measurements show good agreement with the simulation results. The maximum surface temperature deviation of the simulation is 0.9K after 1h and can be explained by uncertainties in the estimation of the rear wall layers’ heat conductivities and capacities as well as measurement uncertainties. The latter are listed in Table 1. 2.5.2 Room model validation The room model validation is conducted applying a mean radiant temperature ( T r ) control in the room. The multi-directional infrared sensor in Fig. 8 was constructed to measure T r in adequate time intervals. Five single IR temperature sensors of type Melexis MLX90614ESF-BAA are used to catch the mean radiant temperatures of the different room directions. With a minimal overlap in fields of view, 90.8% of the room surface can be detected by the sensor combination. The mean radiant room temperature is calculated as the arithmetic mean of all single sensors. The sensor is installed in the center of the ceiling. In addition, the air temperature ( T a ) in the center of the room is measured by a thermocouple (Type K, NiCr-Ni). For validation purposes, the mean radiant temperature is alternately varied between 17°C and 20°C at intervals of 4h. The procedure is performed until the controlled system’s response replicates periodically. Fig. 9 shows the validation results. The heating fabrics reach mean peak powers of approx. 400W resulting in an overall peak power of approx. 2400W. Compared to conventional heat supply systems (radiators and floor heating), the heating-up process of the room is primarily driven by the increasing surface temperatures of the heating fabrics. These heating fabrics show a lower thermal inertia than the room air volume resulting in a faster increase of the mean radiant temperature compared to the air temperature. Mean radiant temperature and air temperature show acceptable agreement during heating-up and temperature drop phases. Simulated ( T r,sim ) and measured ( T r,m ) mean radiant temperatures both follow a characteristic behavior, i.e. an instant drop of approx. 0.4K after the setpoint reduction and a fast increase after the setpoint increase. Within the ongoing temperature drop phase, a diverging drift, resulting in a maximum deviation of 0.6K between T r,sim and T r,m , can be observed. The deviation in the recorded temperatures can be explained by deviations between the real infrared sensor from Fig. 8 and the ideal sensor model resulting from Eq. (15). The non-ideal detection of heating fabrics near the room corners results in a lower mean radiant temperature in the experimental setup. Despite the deviation in absolute values, the validation experiment shows sufficient agreement between the simulated and measured (stationary and transient) thermal behavior of the room and the heating system. Consequently, the model is stated as adequately describing the relevant physics. 3 Control method This article proposes a new control method for direct electric surface heating systems showing an equal utility level compared to a schedule-based operation. Section 3.1 illustrates the structure of the implemented control loop and Section 3.2 explains the control loop elements’ underlying models. 3.1 Control loop Heating fabrics are controlled using the electric voltage (respectively power) as the manipulated variable. With consideration of Eqs. (1) and (2), the control signal is linearized for achieving better control quality. Due to a P T 2 behavior of the controlled system, a PI controller is chosen. Despite slightly differing material parameters, control parameters K P = 10 and T I = 15s (obtained by Ziegler et al. [26]) show similar results for every heating fabric. Optimizing the control parameters by minimizing the time for reaching the setpoint, the mean radiant temperature overshoot could be limited in typical usage cases to 0.5K (Fig. 9). Switching the controlled variable to operative temperature does not affect the control performance since the air temperature signal shows higher inertia than the mean radiant temperature signal. A precise calculation of the operative temperature is defined in ISO 7726 [27] and requires an additional measurement of the local air velocity v a,l . Since a sufficiently accurate measurement of v a,l is not economical in most practical applications, the operative temperature is defined as (17) T op = T a + T r 2 . Following ISO 7726 [27] and considering typical room conditions using surface heating systems ( | T r − T a | ≤ 4°C and v a,l ≤ 0.6ms−1), the maximum measurement error is 0.4K. Since the setpoint temperature can be freely adjusted in case of thermal discomfort, the calculation method is stated as sufficiently accurate. Solar ( Q ̇ S ) and internal ( Q ̇ Int ) heat gains, as well as transmission ( Q ̇ ( T ad , T o ) ) and ventilation ( Q ̇ ( n ) ) heat gains and losses are considered as disturbance variables. The control loop is schematically illustrated in Fig. 10. 3.2 Model based control algorithm Energy savings in unoccupied periods (PU) are realized by reducing the setpoint temperature and thus heat losses to the outdoor environment. The system-specific setpoint temperature in unoccupied periods is chosen such that the setpoint temperature in occupied periods (PO) is reached during a predefined, maximum permissible heating-up time t max . If t max is smaller than the acclimatization time of a human being, the setpoint variation control algorithm shows the same thermal comfort (utility) level as a schedule-based operation. As the subjective perception and thermoregulation response depends on several individual, physiological parameters [28], the control method allows an arbitrary definition of t max . The setpoint temperature T set is defined by Eq. (18). (18) T set = T set,PO , in occupied periods T set,PU = f ( T set,PO , n , T ad , T o , t max ) , in unoccupied periods T set,PU is determined using the simplified room model in Fig. 11. The room envelope is divided into two capacities describing the heated ( C h ) and unheated ( C u ) envelope. R ad and R o define the conductive and transfer resistances from the inner surface to the adjacent rooms and the outdoor environment. R n describes a heat resistance model for air exchange with the outdoor environment. C h and C u are estimated using characteristic room parameters. Differing from Eq. (15), the mean radiant temperature is adapted to the simplified model and defined as (19) T r 4 = Φ T h 4 + ( 1 − Φ ) T u 4 . The measurement point is located in the center of the room. The view factor Φ can be estimated from the area proportions of the heated and unheated surface of the room envelope. For each dynamic boundary condition in unoccupied periods, an optimal setback temperature T set,PU exists. Thereby, a setback temperature is optimal if the operative temperature can be restored exactly within t max in the worst-case scenario. The worst case scenario is represented by the stationary, thermal state of the room in setback mode. In this case, all thermal capacities of the room are discharged to a minimum and the maximum energy is required to reach the occupied state’s setpoint temperature T set,PO again. Fig. 12 shows the iterative algorithm for determining T set,PU for each boundary condition. t describes the particular heating-up time in every iteration step. The specified algorithm and the parameterized model in Fig. 11 are modeled in the Python programming language and can be directly integrated into the control software. Due to the high computing power required for optimization in each time step, setback temperatures for a specific room depending on the dynamic boundary conditions (temperatures of the adjacent rooms T ad and the outdoor environment T o as well as the air exchange rate n ) are evaluated preliminary to the control process. Using the model in Fig. 11 and applying the algorithm in Fig. 12 a setback temperature dataset for different combinations of dynamic boundary conditions can be obtained. Applying a multivariate, linear regression analysis, a setpoint function can be determined according to Eq. (20). (20) T set,PU , t max = min χ 0 + χ 1 n ( T set,PO − T o ) + χ 2 ( T set,PO − T ad ) T set,PO The regression parameters χ 0 = 20 . 8142 , χ 1 = 0 . 0213 and χ 2 = 0 . 0195 are evaluated for the test room in Fig. 1. For boundary temperatures ranging from -20°C to 20°C and air exchange rates ranging from 0.5 to 1, the regression quality R 2 of the determined function is 0.9762. 4 Results Fig. 13 shows a control attempt with the implemented setpoint variation in occupied and unoccupied periods during an 48h time period with predefined boundary conditions. A maximum heating-up time of 5 min and a setpoint temperature of 22°C is set for occupied periods. The outside temperature fluctuates daily between 0°C and 10°C. The temperature of the adjacent rooms varies between 18°C and 22°C. The example demonstrates the functionality of the new proposed control method. During the unoccupied periods, the operative temperature can be reduced by up to 1K. Variations of the outdoor and adjacent room temperature show only marginal impacts on the optimized setpoint temperature. T set,PO is reached exactly 5 min after the start of the first occupied period. 4.1 Sensitivity analysis Potentials for saving energy using the proposed control method are evaluated in a sensitivity analysis. Thereby, parameter variations can be obtained by Table 2. Boundary conditions marked as reference condition hold while one parameter is varied discretely during the specified values. T set,PO is set to 22°C. Weather conditions for the specified locations can be found in Fig. 14. Energy savings due to the proposed control method are presented relative to a schedule-based heating operation in a period of one year. Table 2 shows increasing energy savings if occupied periods appear in smaller proportions. This observation is immediately plausible, since setback periods are longer. Performing the heating operation at night (hotel room) enables less energy savings compared to a daytime operation (office room). This can be explained by lower outdoor temperatures and consequently higher setback temperatures at night. Varying the test room’s location, weather conditions in Cologne appear most favorable for energy savings. Due to higher outdoor temperatures and less convective heat losses because of lower average wind speeds, the control algorithm enables lower setback temperatures in unoccupied periods during the heating period. Analogously, higher air exchange rates increase heat losses due to ventilation and reduce the reheating factor (quotient of total heating power and room’s heat losses). Consequently, lower air exchange rates enable lower setback temperatures in unoccupied periods and enlarge energy savings. The effective specific heat capacity of the room construction does not significantly affect the energy saving potential as the heat capacity of the heating fabrics is such low that heating-up processes occur independently from the unheated room surfaces’ temperatures. Enlarging the heating system’s thermal capacity up to a critical point can enable the unheated room surfaces’ impact on the speed of heating-up processes and thereby reduce the energy saving potential. Varying the maximum permissible heating-up time most significantly affects the energy demand. By increasing the maximum permissible heating-up time, setback temperatures are reduced analogously by the control algorithm. It should be noted that energy savings are compared at different utility levels if the maximum permissible heating-up time is larger than a human being’s acclimatization time. 5 Discussion As the control method enlarges energy savings in occasionally occupied rooms, the heating system recommends itself for usage in office or meeting rooms which are not occupied permanently. Additionally, the proposed heating system is very suitable for rooms which only have to be heated by demand (e.g. hotel rooms). Enabling a non-scheduled possibility to realize an occupancy-based room conditioning, the control method offers a robust alternative to stochastic occupancy models (e.g. Peng et al. [8]). An operative temperature control allows a more precise evaluation of the thermal comfort in indoor environments for heating systems with dominating radiative heat transfer. The developed multi-directional infrared sensor (Fig. 8) is able to measure the operative temperature in combination with a common air temperature sensor. Besides delivering a sufficient measurement precision, the sensor also enables real-time operation. Occupancy can be detected by a set of simple motion sensors observing the whole room or an additional evaluation routine of the sensor data itself. While the new sensor can be mounted at the ceiling, it does not pose an obstacle in the room and also offers architectural advantages compared to conventional globe thermometers. As direct electric heating systems still suffer from high primary energy factors if the operation is dependent on the public electricity grid [30], usage of the heating system is particularly suitable in low-energy buildings. If the complete electricity for heating purposes is provided by renewable generators (e.g. photovoltaic systems), the system enables new alternatives for green heating concepts. Without decentralized renewable generators and storages, a large-scale deployment of the presented, fast-responding heating system causes new challenges for the load management in the public electricity grid. A combination of the fast-response, direct electric heating system with a more inert heating system appears particularly interesting, e.g. as a cost-effective supplement in existing buildings. This would allow the more inert heating system to cover a base load to minimize peak loads and grid load fluctuations caused by the direct electric, low-capacity heating system. 6 Conclusions and outlook Section 4 shows the principal functionality of the newly developed control method. In a demonstrating example, operative temperature could be reduced by up to 1K in unoccupied periods enabling energy savings due to lower temperature differences to the outdoor environment. Thereby, a fast-responding infrared sensor is introduced which allows for adequate, dynamic measurement of the operative temperature. An experiment validates its suitability. In a second step, a sensitivity analysis identifies suitable use cases as well as limits of the proposed method. Depending on the boundary conditions, energy savings of up to 21% could be realized due to the new control method compared to a conventional schedule-based operation. Based on the results, the reheating factor is identified as the main indicator affecting the energy saving potential. The higher the reheating factor, the lower the setback temperature which can be selected during unoccupied periods. The heat capacity of the building construction does not show a significant effect in fast heating-up processes if the heating fabrics are thermally decoupled from the rear wall by an insulation layer. Compared to a conventional air temperature control system, the additional measurement of the mean radiant temperature significantly improves the thermal comfort estimation. A further measurement of the humidity and an estimation of the local air velocity, the activity level and the thermal resistance of the clothing can enable a PMV-based control system [25]. Further research will address an evaluation of the presented control method and heating system in comparison to conventional hot water based heating systems in different usage scenarios. Additionally, a geometrical and dimensional variation of the heating fabrics will be analyzed to find optimal layout solutions for direct electric heating systems using the optimized control method. Besides the temporal optimization, further steps will also include local heating concepts exploiting the surface heating system’s ability to predominantly heat specific areas in large rooms. coredata.dc:description: Conventional heat supply systems for indoor environments merely show annual efficiencies of net energy usage for room heating of 70% to 80% due to an inertia-related oversupply in unoccupied periods. In this study, a new method for increasing this efficiency is introduced. Low-capacity, direct electric heating systems are used to realize an occupancy-equivalent heating concept which only heats the room during occupancy. Using a fast-responding infrared sensor, these heating systems can be controlled by operative temperature, preventing significant oversupplies whilst rapidly heating up a space. A model-based algorithm enables a setback of the room temperature in unoccupied periods while guaranteeing a predefined temperature in the beginning of occupied periods. Thus, the control algorithm enables a utility-equivalent heating operation compared to a non-setback operation. During a first parameter study, net energy savings of up to 21% could be realized due to the new control method compared to a conventional schedule-based operation. The reheating factor of the heat supply system is identified as the main indicator affecting the energy saving potential in occasionally occupied rooms.
coredata.dc:title: Occupancy-equivalent, operative temperature control for an energy-saving operation of direct electric, low-capacity heating systems
